topic.title: HPE Helion 2.0 Development Platform: Install the Development Platform Service Installer

section.p: The installation procedure has changed significantly since the last release. The HDP Installer 2.0, also known as HDPI, is a plugin for the python-openstackclient (OSC). It is able to leverage the authentication, configuration and command line option parsing that is already part of OSC to greatly simplify the installation process.
section.note: You must have satisfied all prerequisites before beginning installation.
Do not source service.osrc, keystone.osrc, or any other file before you begin.

section.title: Download and Set Up the HPE Helion Development Platform Installer

ol.li: Using your preferred web browser, navigate to HPE Helion Download Network (HDN).
Create an account, if you haven't done so already, and log in.
Click the HPE Helion Development Platform category.
From the list of options, click HPE Helion Development Platform 2.0.

Click the blue Download button in the upper right hand corner.The easiest option is to download directly to the physical machine hosting the HPE Helion OpenStack lifecycle manager. If you can not download directly to that location, download the files to portable storage media and then copy the files onto the lifecycle manager. When downloading or copying, make sure there is enough space; the file sizes can be significant.

Create the clouds.yaml configuration file.
Create this directory: mkdir -p ~/.config/openstack/
Create a plaintext file named clouds.yaml in that directory.

Provide the required information for the Platform Configuration section of the clouds.yaml file. If you prefer, you may fully populate the clouds.yaml file at this time for all services you intend to install, but it is not required.
SSH to the HPE Helion OpenStack lifecycle manager (previously known as the deployer node).

Create the virtual environment. In this example, <dev_platform_installer-devplat_installer-#.#.#.gz> is the name of the installation package.
Create the directory. The directory name must exactly match the name of the installation package (<dev_platform_installer-devplat_installer-#.#.#>). Do not rename the directory later. Do not include the file extension in the directory name.sudo mkdir -p /opt/stack/venv/<dev_platform_installer-devplat_installer-#.#.#>
Uncompress the installation package into the directory. sudo tar -C /opt/stack/venv/<dev_platform_installer-devplat_installer-#.#.#> -xzf <dev_platform_installer-devplat_installer-#.#.#.gz>
This process creates a directory under /opt which is owned by root. The owner needs to be changed so that non-admin users can perform service installations. In this example, the user login is stack. sudo chown stack.stack /opt/stack/venv/<dev_platform_installer-devplat_installer-#.#.#.gz>
Test the installer by retrieving a list of installable files. openstack hdpi --os-cloud mycloud list

section.note: If troubleshooting is necessary, include the --debug option in the command to generate highly-detailed output.
